title: Alphabet's Waymo Aims for 2026 Self-Driving Ride-Hailing Launch in Washington, D.C.
summary: Alphabet's self-driving unit Waymo plans to launch its fully autonomous ride-hailing service in Washington, D.C. in 2026. The company is working with policymakers to develop legal frameworks for driverless operations and has already begun moving vehicles to the city. Waymo One is currently active in several major U.S. cities and continues to expand, with over 4 million paid trips in 2024 and more than 200,000 trips weekly. Despite regulatory and safety concerns, including investigations and recalls, Waymo claims its vehicles are much safer than human drivers, citing 81% fewer injury-causing crashes per mile.
key_points: Waymo targets a 2026 launch for fully autonomous ride-hailing in Washington, D.C.
Vehicles are being deployed as regulatory frameworks are established.
Waymo One operates in San Francisco, Phoenix, Los Angeles, and Austin, with expansion to Atlanta and Miami.
Over 4 million paid trips in 2024; 200,000+ weekly trips.
Raised $5.6 billion to support expansion despite regulatory scrutiny.
NHTSA is investigating safety incidents; recalls have been issued for software fixes.
Waymo claims 81% fewer injury-causing crashes per mile than human drivers, based on 50 million rider-only miles.
